Anoosh Bistro is 'sublime'

Anoosh Shariat returns to Louisville dining scene with expanded repertoire

Anoosh Bistro is 'sublime'

Nancy Miller, Special to The Courier-Journal 1:10 p.m. EST December 10, 2014

Anoosh Bistro in Brownsboro Center.(Photo: Sam Upshaw Jr.; The C-J)

Story Highlights

  • Anoosh Bistro
  • Address: 4864 Brownsboro Center
  • Telephone: (502) 690-6585
  • Rating: 4 stars out of 4
5 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The newly debuted Anoosh Bistro is a dazzling display of Anoosh Shariat's talent as a chef and resoluteness as an entrepreneur. The restaurant is sophisticated and sublime. If you're waiting to read a "yes, but," you won't find it in this review.

There is a relaxed luxe about Anoosh Bistro, and I'm not referring only to the ambience. The sleekly styled interior hasn't changed much from Henry's Place, but there is now an undercurrent of glamour that wasn't there before. That's probably attributable to the reverential buzz that permeates the room, wait staff that glide about without being obvious and a parade of food that looks primed for a Bon Appetit magazine cover photo shoot.

Shariat was one of Louisville's finest chefs before he left town a few years ago to work on other projects. Between his departure and his decision to return and set the local food scene ablaze, he expanded his repertoire and further fine-tuned skills that were already perfectly tuned. He is a chef's chef and a diner's dream.

The Carre d'agneau at Bistro Le Relais is lamb chops prepared with a rosemary dry rub, sherry jus, spinach, and gratin dauphinois. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Grand Marnier Souffle at Bistro Le Relais is served with fresh vanilla bean anglaise and prepared to order. It's generous size serves two. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Bistro Le Relais at historic Bowman Field offers "exquisite French cuisine, prepared with only the finest, freshest ingredients" and "first-class service and an intimate, 1940s art-deco interior" according to its website. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
Dining at Bistro Le Relais can include a full view of historic Bowman Field and the regular traffic of arriving and departing small engine planes. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Saint-Jacques at Bistro Le Relais is seared scallops with butternut squash mushroom risotto and orange sage beurre blanc. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Crabcake at Bistro Le Relais is served with spinach and a lemon beurre blanc. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Saumon Fume' is a potato galette topped with smoked salmon and horseradish creme fraiche from the Hors d' Oeuvres menu at Bistro Le Relais at Bowman Field. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen
The Saumon Fume' is a potato galette topped with smoked salmon and horseradish creme fraiche from the Hors d' Oeuvres menu at Bistro Le Relais at Bowman Field. 10/8/14 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J)
Buy Photo Fullscreen

    My friend Jude joined me for a dinner at Anoosh Bistro on a night when every table in the dining room was occupied. Because of the capacity crowd and the restaurant's recent opening, a glitch or two in food or service might have been foreseen. Not long into dinner, it became obvious that glitch isn't a concept acceptable to Shariat or his staff.

    LAST WEEK'S REVIEW: Roux excels at Creole cooking

    There are more than a couple of restaurants in town that exude an attitude that makes diners feel they are fortunate to have been granted a table. Yet another idea that would be unthinkable to the folks at Anoosh Bistro. Jude and I, and from what I could tell, every guest in the restaurant were treated by managers, servers and Shariat himself as exalted visitors.

    The smoked salmon platter ($14) was delectable and arranged with artful precision, a harbinger of what was to come. The salmon platter, as well as pan-seared scallops, wasabi cream and grilled corn relish ($14) and a crab cake ($14), are offered as small plates.

    Although Anoosh Bistro offers a soup du jour, I didn't ask about it because whatever it was wouldn't have swayed me from the Manhattan crab chowder ($8). It is definitely a substantial dish, as would be expected, but Shariat's extravagant rendition of chowder was also sumptuous and copious with crab.

    RELATED: Corbett's chef shares dishes fit for holidays

    Jude and I shared the grilled romaine ($10). The romaine's anchovy dressing and tapenade croutons triumphed with a lusty reciprocity of flavors. On the menu is the requisite house salad. That's where Anoosh Bistro draws the line at the expected. A Kentucky Bibb salad ($8) with bleu cheese, spiced walnuts and apples is punched up with bourbon vinaigrette ($8). An heirloom beet salad ($10) mixes goat cheese and pickled cipollini onions in a shallot balsamic vinaigrette. Roasted hatch onion chutney, Morbier cheese and avocado leche are served with Hass avocado and edamame guacamole ($15).

    Anoosh Bistro's menu is curated and carefully edited, offering rack of lamb ($34), grilled pork tenderloin ($20), beef short rib ($34), filet mignon ($39) and a beef burger ($18). It is with veal scaloppini ($26) that Shariat performs magic by emphasizing prosciutto and sage and letting veal jus magnify the mildness of the veal.

    There were times during our meal that he thrilled us with intensity, one of those times being the lamb shank ($28). Much more than an embellishment, the burgundy sauce is central to the dish's affluence of flavor and character.

    Shariat knows when to reign in opulence. Banana cream pie ($8) was an ode to the kid in all of us.

    When he announced he was opening his restaurant, I was apprehensive that it couldn't live up to his followers' expectations. In many ways, he had been a trailblazer. His reputation had set the bar high and he was a tough act to follow, even for himself.

    Anoosh Bistro is not a rehash of his previous restaurants. Shariat could have taken the easy way out and served up a second helping of what he has always done so well. I don't doubt that he would once again have been a huge success. But, that's not at all what he had in mind. Anoosh Bistro is inventive and fresh. And it is unequivocally classy. It is, after all, named after its chef and partner.

    You can email freelance restaurant critic Nancy Miller at millermadison@aol.com. Follow @WhatNancyThinks on Twitter.

    ANOOSH BISTRO

    Address: 4864 Brownsboro Center

    Telephone: (502) 690-6585

    Web:anooshbistro.com

    Cuisine: New American.

    Alcohol: Full bar.

    Vegetarian: Yes.

    Price range: Expensive.

    Reservations: Yes.

    Credit cards: MC, AE, V, D

    Children's menu: No.

    Smoking: No.

    Access: The restaurant appears to be fully accessible for people using wheelchairs without assistance.

    Hours: Tuesday-Friday, 11 a.m.-2 p.m. and 5-10 p.m.; Saturday, 5-10 p.m.
